{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} '''Vassili Makarovich Kononov'''<ref>[[ECtHR]] usage.</ref> or '''Vasiliy Makarovich Kononov''' ({{lang-ru|Василий Макарович Кононов}}, {{lang-lv|Vasilijs Kononovs}}; 1 January 1923{{spaced ndash}}31 March 2011) was a [[Soviet partisan]] during [[World War II]], who was convicted by Latvian supreme court as a [[war criminal]].<ref>[http://at.gov.lv/lv/pazinojumi-presei/par-notikumiem/2007/septembris/109-augstakas-tiesas-parstavji-strasbura-gust-ieskatu-cilvektiesibu-aizsardziba/ "Augstākās tiesas pārstāvji Strasbūrā gūst ieskatu cilvēktiesību aizsardzībā"], Augstākās Tiesa. 24 septembris 2007. Retrieved 19 March 2015.</ref><ref name=CKL>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=867801&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 "CASE OF KONONOV v. LATVIA"], European Court of Human Rights. 17 May 2010. Retrieved 18 May 2010.</ref> He is the only former Soviet partisan convicted of [[crimes against humanity]].<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Amid_VDay_Festivities_Soviet_Partisan_Braces_For_War_Crimes_Verdict_/2035785.html?page=1&x=1#relatedInfoContainer "Amid V-Day Festivities, Soviet Partisan Braces For War Crimes Verdict"], Radio Free Europe. Claire Bigg. 7 May 2010. Retrieved 18 May 2010.</ref>
Kononov was convicted for his role in three deaths in Mazie Bati, a Latvian village where local inhabitants had denounced alleged partisans who were then killed by German troops. A short time later Kononov led a unit, posing as German [[Wehrmacht]] personnel, into the village and killed nine civilians, including three women, one in the late stages of pregnancy who was burned alive. A Latvian court declared the killing of the three women a war crime. {{TOC limit}}
== Mazie Bati == On 29 February 1944, Latvian villagers from Mazie Bati (Malye Baty) allowed 12 men from the Soviet reconnaissance-sabotage group to stay in their barns. The next day, at six in the morning, the Germans, who Kononov suspected the villagers of aiding, burned and machine-gunned the barns. All 12 partisans, including the leader Major Chugunov, his wife Antonina and their 7-month-old son, were killed.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Interview with Kononov's lawyer, Mikhail Ioffe, and others |series=Россия всегда с тобой |network=[[Voice of Russia]] |airdate=12 December 2007 |transcripturl=http://www.ruvr.ru/main.php?lng=rus&q=54337&cid=28&p=19 December 2007 |language=ru}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |script-title=ru:Европейский суд принял жалобу латвийского партизана Василия Кононова |url=http://www.newsru.com/world/21dec2007/kononov.html |work= |publisher=News.ru |language=Russian |date=21 December 2007 |accessdate=16 April 2009 }} </ref>
On 27 May 1944, a detachment of the Soviet First Latvian Partisan Battalion led by Kononov staged a "counter operation" against the village of Mazie Bati. In this operation, nine villagers were accused of being the "German auxiliaries" (the Latvian armed resistance against the Soviet occupation of Latvia sided with the German invaders in 1941) responsible for the prior incident. Kononov's men were sent to capture the villagers pursuant to an ad-hoc Military Tribunal verdict.<ref>{{cite book |title=Between Stalin and Hitler: Race War and Class War on the Dvina, 1940-46 |last=Swain |first=Geoffrey |year=2004 |publisher=RoutledgeCruzon |location=London & New York |isbn=0-415-33193-5 |oclc=54826052 |pages=140, 247–8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kfd_4o7gOZ8C&hl=en |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Перов |first=Олег |script-title=ru:Последний бой ветерана Кононова |url=http://www.echr.ru/news/msg.asp?id_msg=1279 |date=11 January 2008 |work=Вечерняя Москва | publisher=www.echr.ru |language=Russian |accessdate=16 April 2009 }}</ref>
Kononov and his men conducted the operation wearing German [[Wehrmacht]] uniforms so as not to arouse the suspicion of the villagers. Nine villagers were killed, including three women, one in the late stages of pregnancy who was burned alive. Buildings were burned as well.<ref name="CKL"/><ref>[http://www.baltictimes.com/news/articles/26015/ "ECHR favors Latvia in final Kononov ruling"], Baltic Times. Oskars Magone. 17 May 2010. Retrieved 18 May 2010.</ref>
==War crime prosecution==
===Original conviction and dismissal=== In July 1998, original proceedings against Kononov were commenced by the Latvian Principal Public Prosecutor's Office, whereby in August 1998 he was formally charged and ultimately indicted in December 1998.<ref name=CKL /> Kononov pleaded not guilty at the trial which began in January 1999. Ample evidence of guilt was found by the court where Kononov was in violation of the [[Charter of the International Military Tribunal]] ("IMT") Nuremberg, the [[Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907#Hague Convention of 1907|Hague Convention]] (IV) 1907 and the [[Geneva Convention (IV)]] 1949.<ref name=CKL /> He was found guilty and sentenced to six years imprisonment.<ref name=CKL />
On 25 April 2000, the Criminal Affairs Division in Latvia overturned his conviction on the grounds that it was not clearly established whether Kononov was operating on occupied territory and whether he and his men could be considered combatants, as well as whether the villagers could be considered prisoners of war based on their armament by the Germans.<ref name=CKL /> On 27 June 2000, the Supreme Court of Latvia dismissed the prosecutor's appeal, ultimately setting Kononov free.<ref name=CKL />
===Second investigation and conviction=== On 17 May 2001, Kononov was once again charged by the prosecutor's office following a new investigation. The deaths of six men were deemed justifiable, but the deaths of the three women were deemed an act of banditry, in violation of the law, but ultimately barred by statute of limitations.<ref name=CKL /> The prosecution appealed and on 30 April 2004, the decision of the lower court was overturned and Kononov was found guilty of war crimes, and subsequently jailed.<ref name=CKL /> On 28 September 2004, the Supreme Court upheld the verdict of the court in dismissing Kononov's appeal.<ref name=CKL />
====Appeal to ECHR==== On 19 June 2008,<ref>{{cite news |script-title=ru:Латвия расстанется с миллионами евро: И отдаст их российскому пенсионеру |last=Звегинцев |first=Валентин |work=[[Moskovskij Komsomolets]] |date=27 June 2008 |url=http://mk.ru/blogs/MK/2008/06/27/society/359665/20/ |language=Russian |accessdate=24 July 2008 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Kononov's lawyer Mikhail Ioffe, announced that the [[European Court of Human Rights]] had overturned the Latvian court ruling. He also said that Kononov was seeking {{€|5,187,000}} in compensation for the two and a half years his client spent in a Latvian prison.<ref>{{cite news |script-title=ru:Европейский суд по правам человека удовлетворил иск ветерана войны к Латвии |publisher=[[Interfax]]|date=26 June 2008 |language=Russian |url=http://www.interfax.ru/society/news.asp?id=18972 |accessdate=16 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Biķernieks |first=Aivis |title=Kononova advokāts: bijušais partizāns Eiropas Cilvēktiesību tiesā uzvarējis Latviju |work=Neatkarīgā Rīta Avīze |date=26 June 2008 |url=http://www.nra.lv/zinas/3231-kononova-advokats-bijusais-partizans-eiropas-cilvektiesibu-tiesa-uzvarejis-latviju.htm |language=Latvian |accessdate=24 July 2008}}</ref>
A press release published by the ECHR on 24 July 2008 revealed the Court's decision, establishing, by four votes to three, that the Kononov's case presented a violation of Article 7 (no retrospective punishment) of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]. Kononov was awarded {{€|30,000}} in respect of non-pecuniary damage.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Chamber Judgment: Kononov v. Latvia |publisher=[[European Court of Human Rights]] |date=24 July 2008 |url=http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=838484&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 |accessdate=16 April 2009}}</ref>
On 14 October 2008, the government of Latvia decided to appeal the 24 July judgment.<ref>{{cite news |title=Pārsūdzēs ECT spriedumu Kononova lietā |work=[[Diena]] |location=Riga |date=14 October 2008 |accessdate=15 October 2008 |language=Latvian |url=http://www.diena.lv/lat/politics/politika/parsudzes-ect-spriedumu-kononova-lieta }}</ref> On 9 February 2009, the case Kononov v. Latvia was referred to the Grand Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Cases Accepted for Referral to the Grand Chamber |publisher=[[European Court of Human Rights]] |date=2 February 2009 |url=http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=846915&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 |accessdate=16 April 2009 }}</ref> In May 2009, Lithuania has joined Latvia using its right to participate in the case.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |script-title=ru:Литва получила статус "третьей стороны" по делу Кононова |work=Gazeta.ru |date=6 May 2009 |url=http://www.gazeta.ru/news/lenta/2009/05/06/n_1359046.shtml |language=Russian |accessdate=22 January 2010}}</ref>
=====Final ruling===== In May 2010, the Grand Chamber ruled, by 14 votes to 3, that the case presented no violation of Article 7 ECHR.<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |title=Grand Chamber judgment in case ''Kononov v. Latvia''|url=http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=867803&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 |date=17 May 2010 |work=| publisher=European Court of Human Rights |accessdate=17 May 2010 }}</ref> Under the Hague Regulations of 1907, the court determined Kononov could be punished for failing to meet the regulation criteria, specifically, wearing German Wehrmacht uniforms while carrying out the crimes. The court determined the execution of the villagers was in violation of established international law at the time, as Kononov was only entitled to arrest them, and his conviction was not barred by statute of limitations.<ref name=CKL />
====Support from Russia==== At various times throughout the period of his prosecution for alleged war crimes, Kononov has received official support from the [[Government of Russia]]. In April 2000, immediately before judgement was to be handed down in his appeal with the [[Supreme Court of Latvia]], he was offered citizenship of the Russian Federation by President [[Vladimir Putin]]. Kononov accepted the offer, which entailed giving up his previously-held Latvian citizenship.<ref>{{cite news |script-title=ru:Партизан Кононов отказался от гражданства Латвии |url=http://www.lenta.ru/world/2000/05/25/kononov/ |language=Russian |publisher=[[Lenta.Ru]] |date=25 May 2000 |accessdate=16 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228223645/http://lenta.ru/world/2000/05/25/kononov/ |archivedate=28 February 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On the event of his 80th birthday in 2003, Kononov received personal greetings from the Russian President, delivered at a ceremony held in the Russian Embassy in Riga.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |script-title=ru:Василия Кононова ждут в российском посольстве на торжественную церемонию |url=http://www.1tv.ru/news/n49985 |publisher=[[Channel One (Russia)|Первый канал]] |language=Russian |date=3 January 2003 |accessdate=16 April 2009 }} </ref>
In the hearings of his case at the ECHR, Russia acted as a third party,<ref>{{cite press release |title=Russian MFA Information and Press Department Commentary on ECHR Ruling in Favor of Vasiliy Kononov in WWII Veteran's Case vs. Latvia |publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation]] |date=25 July 2008 |url=http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/e78a48070f128a7b43256999005bcbb3/f1b3183690db0fefc32574910049538b?OpenDocument |accessdate=16 April 2009 }} </ref> and on occasion publicly urged the Court to prioritise Kononov's case.<ref>{{cite news |title=European court urged to give Soviet veteran priority |url=http://www.russiatoday.com/Top_News/2007-03-21/European_court_urged_to_give_Soviet_veteran_priority.html |publisher=[[Russia Today]] |date=21 March 2007 |accessdate=16 April 2009 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Sergey Mironov]], [[speaker (politics)|speaker]] of the [[Federation Council of Russia]], expressed hopes that President [[Dmitry Medvedev]]'s [[Historical Truth Commission]] would also become involved in the Kononov case.<ref>{{cite news |script-title=ru:Кремлевская комиссия займется делом Кононова |url=http://rus.delfi.lv/archive/article.php?id=24659049 |language=Russian |publisher=[[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI.lv]] |date=20 May 2009 |accessdate=24 May 2009}}</ref>
====Impact on Nuremberg legacy==== Kononov's defence team, along with Russia's representative to the ECHR, Deputy Justice Minister [[Georgi Matyushkin]], warned the ruling poses grave dangers to the legal legacy of the [[Nuremberg tribunals]] from World War II.<ref>[http://english.ruvr.ru/2010/05/17/7994664.html "Strasbourg sides with Nazis"], [[Voice of Russia]]. 17 May 2010. Retrieved 18 May 2010.</ref> Matyushkin stated "there are signs of attempts to revise the results of the Nuremberg processes."<ref>[http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=15132916&PageNum=0 "Strasbourg court verdict to Soviet WWII veteran arouses regret in Russia"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ITAR-TASS. 17 May 2010. Retrieved 18 May 2010.</ref> [[William Schabas]], Latvia's counsel at the ECtHR trial, on the contrary, considers that the dissenting minority held Nuremberg judgment to be contrary to the Article 7 of the European Convention on Human Rights.<ref>[http://humanrightsdoctorate.blogspot.com/2010/05/kononov-war-crimes-judgment-issued-by.html Kononov War Crimes Judgment Issued by European Court of Human Rights Grand Chamber]</ref>
====Skepticism==== Kononov's former superior officer, later academician and Soviet functionary, [[Vilis Samsons]], has questioned some of the First Latvian Partisan Battalion's wartime reports upon which the accusations against Kononov are based, alleging the description of the Mazie Bati operation was rife with factual errors and imprecisions.<ref>V. Samsons to H. Strods 20 July 2005, in: {{cite book |title=PSRS kaujinieki Latvijā (1941–1945) |last=Strods |first=Heinrihs |year=2007 |volume=2 |location=Riga |publisher=LU žurnāla "Latvijas Vēsture" fonds |language=Latvian |isbn=9984-643-80-8 |oclc=167627319 |page=355 }}</ref>
==Death== Kononov died in Latvia on 31 March 2011 at the age of 88. In a telegram to Kononov's family, [[Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] stated: "Vasily Kononov selflessly fought the Nazi invaders throughout the years of the Great Patriotic War. He remained loyal to the common bonds forged in battle and defended the truth about the events of those years throughout his entire life."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eng.kremlin.ru/news/1996#sel=3:1,4:25|title=Condolences to family of Great Patriotic War veteran Vasily Kononov|date=1 April 2011|publisher=[[Presidential Press and Information Office]]|accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref>
==Awards== {{Refimprove section|date=April 2009}} In recognition of his wartime service, the [[Soviet Union]] awarded Kononov various honours, including: * the [[Order of Lenin]]; * the [[Order of the Patriotic War]], first class; * the [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]].

Latvia]'' (17 May 2010).
===Press releases===
* {{cite press release |title=Chamber Hearing: Kononov v. Latvia |publisher=[[European Court of Human Rights]] |date=20 September 2007 |url=http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=823541&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 |accessdate=16 April 2009 }} * {{cite press release |title=European Court of Human Rights delivers judgment in Kononov v. Latvia case |publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the [[Republic of Latvia]] |date=25 July 2008 |url=http://www.mfa.gov.lv/en/news/press-releases/2008/July/24-1/ |accessdate=16 April 2009 }}{{Dead link|date=April 2010}} * {{cite press release |title=Facts in the case "Kononovs v.
